p.s: Many people recently discussed the topic whether how important language learning is for UK's future.
Indeed taking into account the rapid changes in our lives due to globalisation this should be considered a current issue.
However we should not opt for panicky reactions.
On the one hand, as Mr. Worne pointed out, universities are engaged in offering language courses and surveys seemingly prood constantly rising importance in the world of business.
And while skills of students in Britain don't relevantly grow, they do in other parts of the world.
On the other hand we should not overestimate the developments.
For example the mentioned decrease of language A-levels by 10.000 over the last 20 years is not that much compared to the number of school children.
Secondly neither technological progress nor the effects of westernization, of which the spread of English language over the world is part, can be ignored or laughed about as John Worne did.
Moreover foreign language skills are unlikely to become a question of life and dead, even if they are important for international business.
CompanysCompanies will find a way to communicate with each other.
This is an alternative interpretation of the fact that UK businesses increasingly perfer to hire abroad (l. 23).
It may be worth considering to rely on the given educational system and let children collect the strings for the bows.
